com.apriori.reflect

Class TypeRef<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.reflect.TypeRef<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type represented by this token

    public abstract class TypeRef<T>
extends Object
    A type token that represents a generic type. Unlike class tokens, which don't adequately support generic classes, this can be used to better represent generic types. Furthermore, it provides access to reifiable generic type information: values for generic type parameters that are known at compile-time.

    When using class tokens to assist with type safety, the limitation is that their generic type parameter is always a raw type:

    // Not valid; won't compile:
    Class<List<String>> clazz = List<String>.class;

    // Compiles, but type of expression has reference to raw type
    Class<List> clazz = List.class;

    // This won't even compile. Argghh!
    Class<List<?>> clazz = List.class;

    TypeRef to the rescue!

    // Compiles, is valid, and is type safe. Yay!
    Class<List<String>> clazz = new TypeRef<List<String>>() { }.asClass();

    Note that, due to type erasure, the actual class instance returned is the same, regardless of generic signature:

    Class<List<String>> clazz1 = new TypeRef<List<String>>() { }.asClass();
    Class<List<Integer>> clazz2 = new TypeRef<List<Integer>>() { }.asClass();
    // Maybe not intuitive, but sadly true:
    // clazz1 == clazz2

    So you have to be careful using these class tokens. For example, they cannot be used as keys in a map to distinguish between List<String> and List<Integer> values (a la the "Typesafe Heterogeneous Container" pattern) since the key values for these will be the same object instance.

    The following snippets show examples of extracting reifiable generic type information from a TypeRef. Consider this complex type reference:

    TypeRef<?> mapType =
      new TypeRef<
        Map<
          Comparable<? super Number>,
          List<Set<String>>
        >
      >() { };

    We'll then extract as much information as possible:

    TypeRef<?> comparableType = mapType.resolveTypeVariable("K");
      // This throws exception since wildcards can't be resolved:
      TypeRef<?> numberType = comparableType.resolveTypeVariable("T");
    TypeRef<?> listType = mapType.resolveTypeVariable("V");
      TypeRef<?> setType = listType.resolveTypeVariable("E");
        TypeRef<?> stringType = setType.resolveTypeVariable("E");

    The following implications are then true:

    mapType.asClass() => Map.class
    mapType.getTypeVariableNames() => [ "K", "V" ]
    comparableType.asClass() => Comparable.class
    comparableType.getTypeVariableNames() => [ "T" ]
    listType.asClass() => List.class
    listType.getTypeVariableNames() => [ "E" ]
    setType.asClass() => Set.class
    setType.getTypeVariableNames() => [ "E" ]
    stringType.asClass() => String.class
    stringType.getTypeVariableNames() => [ ]

    Author:
    Joshua Humphries (jhumphries131@gmail.com)

    • Constructor Detail

      • TypeRef

        protected TypeRef()
        Constructs a new type reference. This is protected so that construction looks like so:

        TypeRef<List<Map<String, Number>>> type =
          new TypeRef<List<Map<String, Number>>>() { };

        Note the curly braces used to construct an anonymous sub-class of TypeRef.

        The generic type must be specified. An exception will be raised otherwise:

        // Bad! Generic type references another type parameter
        // instead of being adequately specified:
        TypeRef<?> type = new TypeRef<E>() { };

        // Bad! Same problem, but with an array type:
        TypeRef<?> type = new TypeRef<E[]>() { };

        // Good! If the generic type is also parameterized, it is
        // okay for its parameter to remain unspecified:
        TypeRef<?> type = new TypeRef<Map<E, String>>() { };

        // Good! You can even use wildcards and bounds:
        TypeRef<?> type = new TypeRef<Map<?, ?>>() { };
        TypeRef<?> type = new TypeRef<List<? extends Number>() { };

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the generic type parameter is not adequately specified. Sadly, this must be a runtime exception instead of a compile error due to type erasure.

        Constructs a type token that represents a specified class.

      • getTypeVariableNames

        public List<String> getTypeVariableNames()

        list of type variable names

      • getTypeVariable

        public TypeVariable<Class<?>> getTypeVariable(String variableName)
        Returns the TypeVariable for the specified generic type variable name.
        Parameters:
        variableName - the variable name
        Returns:
        the TypeVariable for variableName
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified name is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if this type has no type variable with the specified name

      • canResolveTypeVariable

        public boolean canResolveTypeVariable(String variableName)
        Determines if the specified type variable can be resolved into a TypeRef.
        Parameters:
        variableName - the variable name
        Returns:
        true if the specified variable can be resolved
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified name is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if this type has no type variable with the specified name

      • resolveTypeVariable

        public TypeRef<?> resolveTypeVariable(String variableName)
        Resolves the specified type variable into a TypeRef.
        Parameters:
        variableName - the variable name
        Returns:
        a TypeRef that represents the type of variableName
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified name is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if this type has no type variable with the specified name
        IllegalStateException - if this type has no resolution details for the specified type variable, which happens if only a bound (like from a type variable declaration or from a wildcard) is known at compile time

      • isResolved

        public boolean isResolved()
        Returns true if this type token is fully resolved -- which means all type variables can be resolved into TypeRefs and those are also fully resolved.
        Returns:
        true if this type token is fully resolved or false otherwise

      • asClass

        public Class<T> asClass()
        Returns a Class representation of this type. Unlike using normal class tokens (e.g. MyType.class), this token properly supports generic classes.
        Returns:
        a Class

      • asType

        public Type asType()
        Returns a java.lang.reflect.Type representation of this type token.
        Returns:
        a Type

      • superTypeRef

        public TypeRef<? super T> superTypeRef()
        Returns superclass of the current type, as a TypeRef.
        Returns:
        the current type's superclass or null if the current type has no superclass (like if it is Object, an interface, a primitive, or void)

      • interfaceTypeRefs

        public List<TypeRef<? super T>> interfaceTypeRefs()
        Returns the interfaces implemented by the current type, as TypeRefs. This list only includes interfaces directly implemented by this type, not their super-interfaces or interfaces implemented by ancestor classes. The contents and order of the returned list is the same as the contents and order of elements in the array returned by typeRef.asClass().getInterfaces(). If the current type is an interface then this returns its super-interfaces.
        Returns:
        the current type's interfaces or an empty list if the current type does not directly implement any interfaces

      • superTypeRefFor

        public TypeRef<? super T> superTypeRefFor(Class<?> superclass)
        Returns a super type of the current type, as a TypeRef. This could be an ancestor class of the current type or an interface implemented by the current type.
        Parameters:
        superclass - the super type
        Returns:
        a TypeRef representation of the specified super type
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified type is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if the specified type is not a super type of the current type, which can easily be tested using superclass.isAssignableFrom(typeRef.asClass())

      • isSubTypeOf

        public boolean isSubTypeOf(TypeRef<?> ref)
        Determines if this is a sub-type of the specified type token. This has the same caveats as does equals(Object) in that wildcard and type variables are not "captured" and wildcard bounds are not checked for compatibility. If either this type token or the specified other token is not fully resolved then this will return false, even if the Java compiler might treat it as a sub-type due to compatible bounds.
        Parameters:
        ref - a Type Ref
        Returns:
        true if ref represents a sub-type of this

      • isSuperTypeOf

        public boolean isSuperTypeOf(TypeRef<?> ref)
        Determines if this is a super type of the specified type token. This has the same caveats as does equals(Object) in that wildcard and type variables are not "captured" and wildcard bounds are not checked for compatibility. If either this type token or the specified other token are is fully resolved then this will return false, even if the Java compiler might treat it as a super type due to compatible bounds.
        Parameters:
        ref - a TypeRef
        Returns:
        true if ref represents a super type of this

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object other)
        Compares this object to another. This object is equal to another object if they are the same instance or if both objects are TypeRef instances and represent the same types.

        For two TypeRef instances to represent the same types, they must resolve to the same Class and have the same generic type parameters. Note that two seemingly equal TypeRefs with unresolved type variables (for example, two instances that aren't the same instance but both represent List<?>) are considered not equal.

        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        other - the object against which this object is compared
